content: The "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" establishes a program to provide grants for projects addressing railroad infrastructure deficiencies to benefit the public by reducing traffic congestion, transportation emissions, energy usage, and improving railroad operations. Eligible projects will be determined by the Secretary of Transportation. Projects eligible for funding under the "National Rail Infrastructure Program Act" include increasing track capacity, acquiring rights-of-way, improving railroad-road crossings, integrating railroad systems, and repairing track structures. Funding cannot be used for operating expenses, rolling stock acquisition, debt payment, or constructing maintenance or passenger facilities. SEC. 103. INCLUSION IN STATE PLANS. Projects must be included in a long-range transportation plan, a State plan, or a transportation improvement program to be funded under this title. SEC. 104. COST SHARING. States must provide at least 20% of project costs funded under this title. SEC. 105. ALLOCATION OF FUNDS. The Secretary of Transportation allocates 80% of grant funds to States based on a formula considering rail miles and loaded rail cars in each State. The Secretary of Transportation distributes grant funds among States based on a formula considering rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad grade crossings. Additionally, the Secretary has discretion over 20% of the grant amount. The Secretary of Transportation allocates grant funds to States based on rail miles, loaded and unloaded rail cars, and railroad grade crossings. 20% of the grant amount is at the Secretary's discretion for projects of national significance with public benefit emphasis. SEC. 106. LABOR STANDARDS. The Secretary of Transportation must ensure that workers on projects funded under this title are paid prevailing wages as determined by the Davis-Bacon Act. SEC. 107. DISADVANTAGED BUSINESS ENTERPRISES. SEC. 107 of the Act mandates that at least 10 percent of the funds be spent on small businesses owned by socially and economically disadvantaged individuals. Definitions for this section are based on the Transportation Equity Act. SEC. 108 provides additional definitions. SEC. 108 provides definitions for terms used in the Act, including "rail miles" and "railroad" which are crucial for understanding the legislation. SEC. 201 introduces an excise tax on the sale of certain train equipment under a new subchapter in the Internal Revenue Code. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. The tax applies to sales by manufacturers, producers, or importers. A 5% tax is imposed on the sale of specified railroad equipment, including locomotives and rolling stock. The tax applies to sales by manufacturers, producers, or importers. Additionally, a tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on railroad equipment within 6 months of its initial service date, as per regulations set by the Secretary. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of its initial service date, except for replacement parts or accessories. Owners are secondarily liable for the tax. A 5% tax is imposed on the installation of parts or accessories on specified railroad equipment within 6 months of its initial service date, except for replacement parts or accessories. Owners are secondarily liable for the tax. The amendments regarding railroad locomotives and rolling stock will be effective on October 1, 2003. Additionally, a new subchapter on transportation by rail is being inserted into the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. SEC. 202. TAX ON RAIL TRANSPORTATION OF PERSONS OR PROPERTY. A new subchapter on transportation by rail is being added to the Internal Revenue Code of 1986, including sections on transportation of persons and property, along with definitions and special rules. SEC. 4241 imposes a tax on taxable rail transportation of persons, with rates of 5% for commuter rail and 10% for other cases. The tax is paid by the person making the payment. SEC. 4242 outlines regulations for the transportation of property. A 1% tax is imposed on amounts paid for taxable rail transportation of property within or outside the United States. The tax applies to payments made to businesses engaged in transporting property by rail for hire. The tax is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except for payments made outside the United States. The tax imposed on payments for taxable rail transportation of property is paid by the person making the payment subject to tax, except for payments made outside the United States where the tax is paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the United States by the entity providing the last segment of the transportation. The tax on payments for taxable rail transportation of property in the United States is paid by the person to whom the property is delivered in the US by the entity providing the last segment of the transportation. SEC. 4243. DEFINITIONS AND SPECIAL RULES. For tax purposes, "taxable rail transportation" refers to rail travel within the US, excluding mass transit. "Transportation" includes layover time and deadhead service movement. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders. Special rules apply to payments made outside the US for prepaid orders, where the person providing initial transportation must collect the tax. Refunds for tickets purchased without tax payment must deduct any tax due under section 4241. Every person who refunds any amount for a ticket purchased without tax payment must deduct the tax due under section 4241 from the refundable amount. The remaining uncollected tax must be reported to the Secretary. The carrier must pay any uncollected tax on transportation purchased without tax payment, and report the amount to the Secretary. The carrier must pay any uncollected tax on transportation purchased without tax payment, to the extent not collected elsewhere, paid by the carrier providing the initial segment in the United States. SEC. 203. NATIONAL RAIL INFRASTRUCTURE PROGRAM TRUST FUND. The amendments made by this section shall take effect on October 1, 2003. Subchapter A of chapter 98 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended by adding a new section for the National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is created in the Treasury of the United States, funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, and 10 percent of customs duties received after September 30, 2003. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, customs duties, fuel taxes from trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund is funded by taxes on railroad locomotives, rolling stock, customs duties, fuel taxes from trains, and royalties from oil or gas extraction on Federal lands. Amounts in the fund can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act. The National Rail Infrastructure Program Trust Fund, funded by various sources including taxes on railroad locomotives and fuel, can only be used for expenditures related to the National Rail Infrastructure Program Act.
